div1.p: Lazear discusses his work and notes that he is teaching Clinical Microscopy to post-graduate students. He inquires about family members.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, May 9, 1897
div1.p:
I suppose
by this time you are
at Mrs. McCallam's.

I hope you will
tell me all about
May and how she
is getting on.

We were at Aunt
Kates for dinner
yesterday evening
It is very beautiful
at Windsor now.
The old Mill down
by the falls has been
torn down and it
allows an uninterrupted
lview to the falls.

Dr. Knapp called
on Thursday evening
as he was on his
way from Washington
to New York. He asked
for you.

Young Dr. Billings was married last
month to a Miss Hammead of
South Carolina.

Dr. Thayer and I worked up
a case of heart disease, which was
of considerable scientific importance
last year, I doing the bacteriol-
ogical part. Dr. Thayer is
going to Moscow this summer
to the International Medical
Congress, and he offered to
present our report before the
congress and he has just
learned that it is accepted.
These congresses meet every
three years in different countries.
The last one was at Rome
and the one before that at Berlin.

Mabel's sister Jeannie
has a daughter.
It occurred on
Friday and Mabel
had been quite excited
about it all the
week.

I hope you will
write soon and tell
me about Uncle Tom
and Lytt, and the
particulars of Rally
Mc Kelvey's death.
None of us have heard anything except
the bore fact that he was
run over by the cars.

The courses for Post graduates
in medicine has begun and
I am demonstrator in Clinical Micro-
scope, to them as I was with
the undergraduates. At the first
lessen I was surprised to see
among the students, Mrs Burke
or Dr rather Dr. Burke. You will
remember the was at Haverly and
then studied at N.Y. She graduated
and has been she working at
hospitals in N.Y. & Boston.
There mother is at Chicago,
Mabel sends her love and says
the was glad to get your letter
